p.s: In this romantic sonnet, ShakespearShakespeare uses really simple, but effective formal and poetic devices.
At first you can see, that ShakespearShakespeare wrote 14 verses.
They are connected through a cross rhyme scheme.
Which means that the fitting rhymes are crossed.
For example, the first and the third verse do rhyme, and the second and the fourth verse do rhyme.
It's crossed and often recognized as abab-system.
He wrote 14 verses, which means that the sonnet has seven pairing rhymes.
It's very significant that he uses many alliterations, which means that words start with the same letter.
For example, he used it at the second verse with travel tired (v. 2), which is better recognizable for our minds.
The human mind can recognize things better when they get repeated or when they rhyme.
Same stating letters make it also sound better.
In verse nine and ten he also uses alliterations, to itensifyintensify the meaning and the expression behind his words.
Save [...] souls, [...] sight [...] shadow [...] sightless(v. 9f.), those alliterations, over two, not rhyming, verses give them power and also highlights them.
I would say that this two verses are the most important in the whole Sonnet, because they are highlighted, through the alliterations, and they describe exactly what he wants to express.
Even though iI can't see, my soul still sees you, in the darkest times I only think of you, even my soul is deeply in love/connected with you are a couple of things he wants to express.

With the Anapheranaphora, which means that the beginning of sentences are repeaed or the same by day my limbs, by night my mind (v. 13) he expresses that his whole life, his whole body and personality is focused on the person he loves.
HIs whole life is influenced by her/him.
ShakespearShakespeare doesn't use a lot of devices alone by the words he chooses, he creates a beautiful atmosphere.
He still manages to express exactly what he wants to say.
It's impressive.
